chapters.name: How Politicians Use Numbers to Persuade
topics: Why do politicians rely so heavily on statistics — and what makes numbers more persuasive than qualitative arguments?
What are the most common ways politicians misuse statistics — cherry-picking, misleading baselines, and false precision?
How does framing change the impact of a number — '3% unemployment' vs. '5 million people without jobs'?
What is the difference between a statistic that is technically true but deeply misleading and one that is fabricated?
How do politicians use percentage changes vs. absolute numbers to make things sound bigger or smaller?
What is the role of context — and why is a number without context almost always misleading?
How do you develop the instinct to question numbers rather than accept them at face value?

chapters.name: Finding Original Data and Reports
topics: Where do the numbers in political claims actually come from — and how do you trace them to the source?
What are the major government data sources — BLS, Census, CBO, BEA — and what does each track?
How do you read a government report or data release — and what should you look for?
What are think tanks — and how do left-leaning and right-leaning think tanks produce different analyses of the same data?
How do you find the original study behind a news headline — and why is the study often more nuanced than the headline?
What are the most useful free data sources for checking political claims — and how do you use them?
What do you do when the original data is behind a paywall, not publicly available, or has been taken down?

chapters.name: Understanding Polls and Margins of Error
topics: How do political polls work — sample selection, question design, weighting, and reporting?
What is a margin of error — and why does a 3-point lead in a poll with a 4-point margin of error mean very little?
Why have polls become less accurate in recent years — response rates, social desirability bias, and hard-to-reach voters?
How do you evaluate whether a specific poll is credible — sample size, methodology, and who conducted it?
What is the difference between a registered voter poll, a likely voter poll, and an adult poll — and which matters most?
How do poll aggregators like FiveThirtyEight and RealClearPolitics combine polls — and why is that better than any single poll?
What are push polls — and how are they used to spread misinformation disguised as polling?

chapters.name: Recognizing Misleading Graphs and Charts
topics: How do misleading graphs distort reality — truncated axes, manipulated scales, and cherry-picked time periods?
What is a truncated y-axis — and how does it make small changes look dramatic?
How do dual-axis charts create false correlations — and why should you be suspicious of them?
What are the most common types of misleading visualizations used in political arguments?
How do pie charts, bar charts, and line graphs each have specific ways they can mislead?
What should you check first when looking at any graph — axis labels, scale, time period, and data source?
How do you create accurate mental images of data — and resist the emotional impact of misleading graphics?

chapters.name: Economic Claims: Jobs, GDP, and Cost of Living
topics: What do politicians mean when they talk about 'creating jobs' — and how is job creation actually measured?
What is GDP — and why is it both the most-cited and most-misunderstood economic indicator?
What is the unemployment rate — and why does the official number exclude many people who can't find work?
How do politicians use inflation numbers — and why does 'inflation is down' not mean 'prices are down'?
What is the difference between median income and average income — and why does it matter for evaluating living standards?
How do politicians take credit for economic trends that started under their predecessors — or blame successors for problems they caused?
What economic statistics should every voter understand — and where do you find them?

chapters.name: Crime and Safety Claims
topics: How do politicians use crime statistics — and why is 'crime is up' or 'crime is down' almost always more complicated than it sounds?
What is the difference between reported crime, surveyed crime, and actual crime — and which data is most reliable?
How do politicians use anecdotes — individual horrifying cases — to make statistical claims about trends?
What is the relationship between immigration and crime — and what does the data actually show?
How do local crime numbers get used in national political arguments — and why is that misleading?
What are the most reliable sources for crime data — FBI UCR, NCVS, and local police reports — and what are their limitations?
How does fear of crime differ from actual risk — and how do politicians exploit that gap?

chapters.name: Immigration Claims
topics: What data exists on immigration — legal entries, undocumented estimates, asylum applications, border encounters?
How do politicians distort immigration numbers — conflating legal and illegal immigration, using raw numbers vs. rates?
What is the actual economic impact of immigration — and what does the research show?
How do claims about immigrants and crime hold up against the data?
What is the difference between border encounters, apprehensions, and actual entries — and why does the distinction matter?
How do politicians use immigration statistics selectively to support opposing conclusions?
What are the most reliable sources for immigration data — and how do you access them?

chapters.name: Healthcare and Social Program Claims
topics: How do politicians use healthcare statistics — costs, coverage rates, outcomes — and how are they frequently misleading?
What is the actual cost of Medicare, Medicaid, and Social Security — and how do politicians misrepresent those numbers?
How do claims about 'government spending' change depending on whether you use total dollars, per capita, or percentage of GDP?
What are the most common misleading claims about the Affordable Care Act — and what does the data show?
How do politicians compare US healthcare to other countries — and why are those comparisons often flawed?
What statistics matter most for evaluating social programs — costs, outcomes, or both?
How do you check a politician's claim about a specific program — where do you find the numbers?

chapters.name: Climate and Environmental Claims
topics: How do politicians use climate data — and what are the most common ways they misrepresent it?
What is the difference between weather and climate — and how do politicians exploit the confusion?
How do claims about the cost of climate action compare to the cost of inaction — and where do the numbers come from?
What is cherry-picking in climate data — choosing start and end dates to show warming or cooling trends?
How do energy industry-funded studies differ from independent climate research — and how do you tell the difference?
What are the most reliable sources for climate data — NASA, NOAA, IPCC — and what do they say?
How do you evaluate competing claims about renewable energy costs, fossil fuel subsidies, and energy employment?

chapters.name: Education and Budget Claims
topics: How do politicians claim to support or undermine education — and what do the funding numbers actually show?
What is the federal vs. state vs. local breakdown of education funding — and why does that matter for evaluating claims?
How do politicians use standardized test scores, graduation rates, and international rankings to make arguments?
What are the most common misleading claims about government budgets — debt vs. deficit, discretionary vs. mandatory?
How do tax proposals get misrepresented — and how do you find independent analyses of tax plans?
What is the national debt — and how do politicians use it selectively depending on who's in power?
Where do you find reliable budget analyses — CBO, Tax Foundation, Tax Policy Center — and how do their approaches differ?

chapters.name: Fact-Checking Organizations and How to Use Them
topics: What are the major fact-checking organizations — PolitiFact, FactCheck.org, Snopes, Washington Post Fact Checker?
How do fact-checkers evaluate claims — what is their methodology?
Are fact-checkers biased — and how do you evaluate the fact-checkers themselves?
What is the difference between a fact-check and an opinion — and how do some people confuse them?
How do you use fact-checking sites effectively — searching claims, reading methodology, and checking ratings?
What are the limitations of fact-checking — claims that are technically true but misleading, matters of interpretation?
How does fact-checking fit into a broader practice of informed citizenship?

chapters.name: Building Your Political Fact-Checking Practice
topics: What is a practical workflow for checking a political claim you hear in a debate, speech, or social media post?
How do you check claims in real time — during a debate, a rally, or a news broadcast?
What are the most important bookmarks, apps, and tools for political fact-checking?
How do you avoid confirmation bias — the tendency to fact-check claims you disagree with and accept those you agree with?
How do you talk about fact-checking with people who distrust fact-checkers?
What is the responsibility of a citizen in a democracy to verify the claims of their elected officials?
How do you maintain the habit of fact-checking without becoming cynical about all political speech?
